solution_04_inferential_statistics/02_confidence_intervals/03_conf_int_prop_v2

video

First, determine \(z^\star\) such that \(P(|Z|<z^\star)=0.9\). It can help to draw a sketch.


The entire area under the density curve is 1. Thus, we can determine the areas of the tails (using symmetry). \[\text{area of each tail} = \frac{1-\gamma}{2} = \frac{1-0.9}{2} = 0.05\]


Determine a leftward area with boundary \(z^\star\). \[P(Z<z^\star)=\gamma + \frac{1-\gamma}{2}= 0.9+0.05=0.95\]


We rephrase the puzzle. We wish to determine \(z^\star\) such that \(P(Z<z^\star)=0.95\). This is easy to determine using a \(z\)-table, qnorm in R, norm.inv in spreadsheets, or other methods for evaluating the quantile function.

## Using R's qnorm:
qnorm(0.95)
## [1] 1.644854

\[P(Z<1.64)=0.95\] In the original phrasing,

\[P(|Z|<1.64)=0.9\]

So, \(z^\star = 1.64\). Now, use the given expressions to evaluate the boundaries.


  1. Lower bound = \(~0.5144-1.64\sqrt{\frac{(0.5144)(1-0.5144)}{243}} ~=~ 0.46\)
  2. Upper bound = \(~0.5144+1.64\sqrt{\frac{(0.5144)(1-0.5144)}{243}} ~=~ 0.57\)
